content.title: Infrainguinal Vein Graft Failure
content.definition: Vein graft failure is thrombotic occlusion or functional stenosis of autogenous vein bypass grafts, classified by timing as early (<30 days), intermediate (30 days-2 years), or late (>2 years), each with distinct etiologies and management strategies.

technical_causes_early.anastomotic: Stricture, kinking, tension, poor suture technique
technical_causes_early.conduit: Inadequate vein diameter, retained valve, injury, sclerotic vein

intimal_hyperplasia.pathophysiology: Smooth muscle cell proliferation in response to injury
intimal_hyperplasia.surveillance: Duplex ultrasound can detect before occlusion

clinical_presentation.acute_occlusion: Sudden limb ischemia, worse than original presentation
clinical_presentation.stenosis: Recurrent claudication, return of rest pain
clinical_presentation.threatened: Diminished pulses, falling ABI, duplex abnormality

threatened_graft.endovascular: PTA Â± stent for focal lesions

occluded_graft.acute: Thrombolysis, thrombectomy, then address underlying lesion
occluded_graft.chronic: New bypass (if conduit available) vs amputation

outcomes.importance: Early detection of stenosis preserves graft patency

learning_objectives: Classify vein graft failure by timing and etiology
Describe role of intimal hyperplasia in intermediate graft failure
Outline duplex surveillance protocol for vein grafts
Compare treatment options for stenotic vs occluded grafts
clinical_pearls: Early failure (<30 days) is usually technical - re-explore and fix the problem
Intermediate failure (30 days-2 years) is typically intimal hyperplasia
Duplex surveillance can detect stenosis before graft thrombosis
PSV ratio >3.5 indicates significant stenosis requiring intervention
